headline: Microsoft to cut about 4% of jobs amid hefty AI bets
summary: STORY: :: Microsoft to cut about 4% of jobs amid hefty AI bets:: The tech giant is looking to rein in costs amid hefty investments in artificial intelligence infrastructure:: The Windows-maker had about 228,000 employees worldwide as of June 2024:: The company had pledged $80 billion in capital spending for its 2025 fiscal year:: But the soaring cost of scaling its AI infrastructure has weighed on its margins:: Microsoft said it plans to reduce organization layers and streamline its products, procedures and roles:: Microsoft confirmed to Reuters that its gaming division was impacted by the layoffs:: Big Tech peers like Meta, Amazon and Alphabet's Google have also announced job cuts in the past year

raw.headline: Microsoft to cut about 4% of jobs amid hefty AI bets

headline: Tesla stock rises despite sales miss, Microsoft to cut 9K jobs
summary: Yahoo Finance's John Hyland takes a closer look at some of the top stories on Wall Street as part of today's Market Minute. Investors are shrugging off the latest ADP report showing an unexpected decline in job growth for June. Tesla (TSLA) stock is climbing despite the company reporting a 13% drop in vehicle deliveries in its second quarter. Microsoft (MSFT) plans to cut 9,000 jobs in its second major workforce reduction this year. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: Microsoft to cut workforce by up to 4% in latest round of layoffs

headline: Xbox Hit With Latest Mass Layoff Including Multiple Game Cancelations As Microsoft Cuts 9,100 Jobs [Update]
summary: Reports and rumors of massive layoffs at Xbox have been building since late last month, and the first blood has now been spilled. Bloomberg reports that Candy Crush maker King is cutting 200 employees, or roughly 10 percent of its 2,000-person headcount, with layoffs also underway at other European offices including those of Bethesda parent company ZeniMax.

headline: Microsoft Lays Off 9,000 Workers
summary: Microsoft  is laying off slightly less than 4% of its global workforce—around 9,000 workers—in another major round of layoffs, the company confirmed Wednesday.  The layoffs come as no surprise after The Wall Street Journal reported last month that  Microsoft  was planning to slash several thousand jobs.  The move comes as tech companies trim headcount amid increased investments in artificial intelligence.

raw.headline: Microsoft Lays Off 9,000 Workers
raw.summary: Microsoft  is laying off slightly less than 4% of its global workforce—around 9,000 workers—in another major round of layoffs, the company confirmed Wednesday.  The layoffs come as no surprise after The Wall Street Journal reported last month that  Microsoft  was planning to slash several thousand jobs.  The move comes as tech companies trim headcount amid increased investments in artificial intelligence.

headline: Centene, Microsoft, Paramount: Trending Tickers
summary: Centene (CNC) stock is plummeting after the health insurer withdrew its 2025 profit guidance, citing lower market growth and high Medicaid costs. Microsoft (MSFT) is reportedly planning to cut over 9,000 jobs, according to the Seattle Times, adding to layoffs earlier this year as part of a broader workforce reduction. Paramount (PARA) agreed to a $16 million settlement with former President Trump over a lawsuit alleging election interference related to an interview of former Vice President Kamala Harris. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: 2 Artificial Intelligence (AI) Stocks to Buy Before They Soar to $5 Trillion, According to Select Wall Street Analysts

Nvidia is the market leader in AI accelerator chips and networking equipment, and the stock price is reasonable.  Microsoft is monetizing AI across its software and cloud computing businesses, but the stock is rather expensive.

headline: Merger of French and Swiss business software firms heralds new unicorn
summary: ZURICH (Reuters) -A merger between French business software provider LumApps and its Swiss peer Beekeeper will create a new unicorn worth about $1.1 billion, the two companies said.  The deal announced on Wednesday, which is due to complete this month, is backed by British private equity group Bridgepoint, which was previously a major shareholder in LumApps and will hold a majority stake in the new firm.  The new firm's headquarters will be in Lyon, the home of LumApps, whose CEO Sebastien Ricard will lead the business.

raw.headline: Merger of French and Swiss business software firms heralds new unicorn
raw.summary: ZURICH (Reuters) -A merger between French business software provider LumApps and its Swiss peer Beekeeper will create a new unicorn worth about $1.1 billion, the two companies said.  The deal announced on Wednesday, which is due to complete this month, is backed by British private equity group Bridgepoint, which was previously a major shareholder in LumApps and will hold a majority stake in the new firm.  The new firm's headquarters will be in Lyon, the home of LumApps, whose CEO Sebastien Ricard will lead the business.

headline: China Is Quickly Eroding America’s Lead in the Global AI Race
summary: Chinese artificial-intelligence companies are loosening the U.S.’s global stranglehold on AI, challenging American superiority and setting the stage for a global arms race in the technology.  In Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia, users ranging from multinational banks to public universities are turning to large language models from Chinese companies such as startup DeepSeek and e-commerce giant  Alibaba  as alternatives to American offerings such as ChatGPT.

raw.headline: China Is Quickly Eroding America’s Lead in the Global AI Race

headline: Should You Buy Microsoft Stock Now or Wait for a Dip?
summary: Microsoft is trading at all-time highs and nearly 40 times its trailing earnings.  Its growth rate has been higher than normal as the business has benefitted from artificial intelligence.  Shares of Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) are up 18% this year (returns as of June 27), and that has pushed the stock to a new all-time high.
